courses.name: Introduction to Sociology
courses.description: Nature of organization and activities of human groupings-family, community, crowd, social class, etc.; structure, function of institutions; social influences shaping personality, behavior, social change. No credit for both SOCIOL 1000 and RU_SOC 1000.

courses.name: Introduction to Sociology Honors
courses.description: Nature of organization and activities of human groupings-family, community, crowd, social class, etc.; structure, function of institutions; social influences shaping personality, behavior, social change. No credit for both SOCIOL 1000 and RU_SOC 1000.

courses.name: Social Problems
courses.description: Introduces a sociological perspective on what constitutes social problems and their impact on individuals and societies. Emphasizes critical thinking skills. Topics covered may include poverty, inequalities of gender, race, class, religion, education, and political power, the environment and global conflicts among others.

courses.name: Population and Ecology
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 1120 and PEA_ST 1120). Changes in the structure and characteristics of population groups and their relationship to both human and non-human aspects of the biophysical environment.

courses.name: The Female Experience: Body, Identity, Culture
courses.description: (same as WGST 1360). Study of the experience of being female in American culture. Course will focus on development of women's identities through such topics as: sexuality, reproduction, self-image, rape and health care.

courses.name: Social Deviance
courses.description: Survey of approaches to the study of behaviors commonly regarded as deviant such as crime, sexual abuse, substance abuse, mental illness, etc.

courses.name: Topics in Sociology-Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Particular topics may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.

courses.name: Critical Dialogues: Nonviolence in Peace/Democracy Movements
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2182). History and theory of movements for peace, justice, and democracy. Development of violent and nonviolent tactics and factions in movements; relationship to state authority. Cases such as Gandhi's Independence, American Civil Rights, Arab Spring, and Occupy movements.

courses.name: Critical Dialogues: Nonviolence in Peace/Democracy Movements - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2182W). History and theory of movements for peace, justice, and democracy. Development of violent and nonviolent tactics and factions in movements; relationship to state authority. Cases such as Gandhi's Independence, American Civil Rights, Arab Spring, and Occupy movements.

courses.name: Social Inequalities
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2200). Survey of inequalities based upon criteria such as race, ethnicity, sex, age, religion and social class in contemporary societies. Focus on dynamics by which privilege and inequalities are structured.

courses.name: The Black Americans
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2210). Analysis of history of blacks in the United States. Assessment of contemporary black community in terms of its institutions, styles of life, patterns of work and intergroup relations.

courses.name: Social Perspectives on Aging
courses.description: Survey of basic knowledge in social gerontology, aging and old age in American society. Analysis of changes as individuals age, differences among old people, social problems of the aged.

courses.name: Youth, Islam, and Global Cultures
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2255). Youth subcultures and the social issues and problems faced by youth, focusing on the Islamic world and Muslim immigrants, in the United States and elsewhere. Social and behavioral theories and concepts such as paths to modernization, Orientalism, post-colonialism, population movements, social construction, identity, and recognition will be illustrated.

courses.name: Race, Democracy, and Violence in Cuba and Haiti
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2280, GEOG 2280).  A sociological approach to understand race/ethnicity, identity, citizenship, human rights, violence, and political and economic systems in the Caribbean. Comparisons of the culture, politics, and historical trajectories of Cuba and Haiti using Post-Colonial and Feminist theories. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Race, Democracy, and Violence in Cuba and Haiti - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2280, GEOG 2280).  A sociological approach to understand race/ethnicity, identity, citizenship, human rights, violence, and political and economic systems in the Caribbean. Comparisons of the culture, politics, and historical trajectories of Cuba and Haiti using Post-Colonial and Feminist theories. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nuclear Weapons: Environmental, Health and Social Effects
courses.description: (same as HLTH_SCI 2200 and PEA_ST 2200).  Environmental consequences of the nuclear arms race, "regional" nuclear war, and weapons testing for human health, agriculture, and society. Examining "a world without nuclear weapons"; political dialogue on proliferation; Iran, North Korea, and nuclear weapons conventions. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nuclear Weapons: Environmental, Health and Social Effects - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as HLTH_SCI 2200 and PEA_ST 2200).  Environmental consequences of the nuclear arms race, "regional" nuclear war, and weapons testing for human health, agriculture, and society. Examining "a world without nuclear weapons"; political dialogue on proliferation; Iran, North Korea, and nuclear weapons conventions. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Critical Dialogs: Global Environmental Policy Conflicts
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2284). Climate change, water supplies, food, sustainability, industrialization, and chemical, oil, radioactive pollution.  Activity of transnational corporations, social harm, and formulation of international policies.  Analysis of alternatives using criteria of justice: distribution, recognition, participation, legality.

courses.name: Large Corporations, Economic Crisis, Social Responsibility
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2285). Institutional power of the corporate CEO; ethical regulatory restraint.  Historical contexts of economic crisis.  Theories of justice, alternative concepts of justice in popular culture.  Politics of policy issues in prosecution and criminalization of corporate behavior.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Technological Futures, National Security, and Civil Liberties
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2286). Contemporary practices and future trends in data collection and mining by the NSA and by businesses. The interplay of government and corporate power, and possibilities of regulation and maintenance of privacy and civil liberties. The development of digital intellectual copyright and its consequences on patterns of dissemination of knowledge.

courses.name: Technological Futures, National Security, and Civil Liberties - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2286). Contemporary practices and future trends in data collection and mining by the NSA and by businesses. The interplay of government and corporate power, and possibilities of regulation and maintenance of privacy and civil liberties. The development of digital intellectual copyright and its consequences on patterns of dissemination of knowledge.

courses.name: Self and Society
courses.description: Analysis of the self in modern society.  Topics covered include social interaction, social perception, language and learning, the sociology of emotions and the social construction of identity.

courses.name: Culture and Mass Media
courses.description: Sociological study of modern folk, local, popular and mass cultural production and consumption; mass media, diffusion, change, differentiation.

courses.name: Social Research I
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 2950). Introduction to principles of methodology; theory and research; survey of basic research designs and perspectives; preparation for understanding and conducting social research.

courses.name: Urban Sociology
courses.description: Urbanism as a world phenomenon; ecological, demographic characteristics of cities; organization of urban society including status systems, occupational structure, formal and informal associations, racial and cultural relations, forms of communication, housing, city planning.

courses.name: Recent Theories in Sociology
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 3100). Introduction to major theoretical positions and issues in contemporary American sociology. Logical and intellectual structure of major theoretical schools: functionalism, conflict, exchange, symbolic interaction, phenomenological-ethnomethodological theories.
courses.prerequisites: Sociology majors only. Non-sociology majors may petition the instructor to add the course

courses.name: Class, Status, and Power
courses.description: Study of the structure of wealth, poverty, prestige, and power.  Concepts of social justice in political, economic and legal issues and policies.  Provides student engagement in research.

courses.name: Sociology of Globalization
courses.description: Globalization's origin and dynamics; the social and political effects of globalization: countervailing forces to economic globalization, in particular reassertions of "traditional" identities, labor movements, new social movements, and the global democracy movement.

courses.name: Education and Social Inequalities
courses.description: Examination of the ways in which inequalities are constructed, reproduced, maintained or transformed by and within educational institutions. Particular attention will be given to inequalities based on gender, race, and social class.

courses.name: Youth in Today's World
courses.description: Study of what factors influence the development of youth in today's society. Examined are types of behavior such as mating, deviance and the role of schools, parents, TV and friendship groups.

courses.name: Queer Theories/Identities
courses.description: (same as WGST 3300). Analysis of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT) and queer identities in culture and society with an emphasis on the contributions of queer theory and other GLBT standpoint theories to sociology and the study of society.

courses.name: Queer Theories/Identities - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as WGST 3300). Analysis of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT) and queer identities in culture and society with an emphasis on the contributions of queer theory and other GLBT standpoint theories to sociology and the study of society.

courses.name: Social Psychology
courses.description: Survey of theories and research concerned with the ways in which individuals construct social situations and are affected by them. Topics covered include self-identities, social influence, personal relationships, prejudice and discrimination.

courses.name: Social Psychology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Survey of theories and research concerned with the ways in which individuals construct social situations and are affected by them. Topics covered include self-identities, social influence, personal relationships, prejudice and discrimination.

courses.name: Sociology of Gender
courses.description: (same as WGST 3320). Study of the ways in which femininities and masculinities are constructed in American society with particular attention to gender ideologies and the gendered nature of the social structure.

courses.name: Environmental Justice
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3330). Environmental justice refers to the ways in which the "cost and benefits" of modern industrial society are distributed among social groups.  This course is concerned with justice, not as an abstract concept, and inequality not in terms of numbers in a bank account.  Social justice or inequality are lived, embodied experiences.  An individual's likelihood of experiencing environmental harm is related to intersecting gender, race and class formations, among other things.  Justice or inequality is not only embodied, it also happens in places--national and regional differences matter.  In this course we will look at some of the extensive literature documenting the ways in which communities of color and poor communities are subject to disproportionate environmental risks.  In addition, we will focus on gender as an important category in understanding environmental inequality.

courses.name: Politics of the Media
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3400). In this course we study critical thinking skills and use them to compare and contrast U.S. media coverage of current issues with media in other parts of the world. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Politics of the Media - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3400). In this course we study critical thinking skills and use them to compare and contrast U.S. media coverage of current issues with media in other parts of the world. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The Family
courses.description: Families, kin and households as interacting groups; roles, socialization, problems, structural change; family in relation to other social institutions; historical, cultural and class variations.

courses.name: The Sociology of Sport
courses.description: The role of sport in modern society. Includes violence in sport; politics and economics of sport; male, female, and racial inequalities; and international comparisons of sport structures.

courses.name: Sociology of Health
courses.description: A survey of sociological thinking and research on health, health problems, health occupations and health services. How these are shaped by the society. Problems faced by individuals and the system. Potential solutions to problems.

courses.name: The Sociology of Religion
courses.description: Sociology of religious experience, action, organization, movements and social change; contemporary trends, including mainline and new religions, civil religion, secularization.

courses.name: Technology and Society
courses.description: In the last few decades science and technology have permeated our lives as never before.  This has led to wide ranging intellectual debates and social movements in and around the issue of relationship between science, technology, and society.  This course, which is organized on a lecture-seminar format, will critically investigate different aspects of the relationship between science, technology, and society.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Technology and Society - Writing Intensive
courses.description: In the last few decades science and technology have permeated our lives as never before.  This has led to wide ranging intellectual debates and social movements in and around the issue of relationship between science, technology, and society.  This course, which is organized on a lecture-seminar format, will critically investigate different aspects of the relationship between science, technology, and society.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Public Opinion and Communication
courses.description: Nature of public opinion; processes of opinion formation; special publics, pressure groups; effects of communication through personal contacts and mass media; propaganda, censorship; opinion surveying.

courses.name: Collective Behavior
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3520). Analysis of crowd behavior and related phenomena: rumors, disasters, fashions. Social responses to unclear, dangerous or unjust conditions. The dynamics of conflict, consensus and change.

courses.name: Collective Behavior - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3520). Analysis of crowd behavior and related phenomena: rumors, disasters, fashions. Social responses to unclear, dangerous or unjust conditions. The dynamics of conflict, consensus and change.

courses.name: New Media, Conflict and Control
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3522). This course will explore the increasing role of new media tools in conflict and surveillance. Examples from recent conflicts will illustrate how citizens and regimes use new media to communicate, report, mobilize, monitor, and/or control. Students will utilize new media as they research instances of democracy and control.

courses.name: Criminology
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3600). Sociology of law; constitutional, psychological, sociological theories of criminal behavior; process of criminal justice; treatment of corrections; control of crime.

courses.name: Institutions and Society
courses.description: Institutions of societies with focus on institutional arrangements (economy, polity, media, education, religion); organizational structures; interorganizational networks; interrelations of institutional sectors.

courses.name: The Sociology of Work
courses.description: Analysis of occupational, professional aspects of American society. Division of labor; occupational mobility; work and the self; colleagueship and informal organizations of work.

courses.name: Social Research I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 3950W). Introduction to principles of methodology; theory and research; survey of basic research designs and perspectives; preparation for understanding and conducting social research.

courses.name: Topics in Sociology-Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Particular topics may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Feminist Research and Criticism
courses.description: (same as WGST 4110). Examination of both feminist critiques of traditional social research and recent, feminist-oriented research that attempts to answer these criticisms.

courses.name: Social Statistics
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 4120). Descriptive statistics and bivariate quantitative analysis techniques commonly used by social scientists. Includes coverage of parametric and non-parametric methods. Introduction to computer analysis.

courses.name: Social Inequalities
courses.description: Examination of theories and research concerned with inequalities based on social class, gender, and race-ethnicity. M.A. core course for sociology students.

courses.name: Aging and the Life Course
courses.description: Course will take a life course perspective on the sociological aspects of aging in contemporary American society. Begins with birth, then childhood, adolescence, emergent adulthood, middle life, old age, and death. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: At least three credits in Sociology prior to enrollment is preferred

courses.name: Race and Ethnic Relations
courses.description: The experience of racial and ethnic minorities; inequality, assimilation, ethnic and racial conflict, accommodation.

courses.name: Women, Development, and Globalization
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4230 and WGST 4230 and PEA_ST 4230). Examines the history and structure of "development" discourse and practices. Stresses the interconnections and impact on women globally. Reviews women's strategies in defining and instituting programs to improve quality of life in communities.
courses.prerequisites: BL_STU 1332, BL_STU 2200; SOCIOL 2200; WGST 1332 or WGST 2010

courses.name: Social Perspectives on Gender and Emotion
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4235, WGST 4235; cross-leveled with BL_STU 7235, SOCIOL 7235, WGST 7235). Examines theories of affect and emotions, the social contexts and the implications for human development and behavior, with special emphasis on sex, gender, race, class and culture. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: WGST 1332 or WGST 1360; SOCIOL 1360 or SOCIOL 2300; BL_STU 1332 or BL_STU 2200; junior standing

courses.name: Social Demography
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 4315). General demographic theories; age, sex, and ethnic composition of population; fertility, mortality and migration as components of population change; social, economic and political implications of demographic trends.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 1000 or RU_SOC 1000 and junior standing

courses.name: Culture, Identity and Interaction
courses.description: Examines the interplay between culture, identity, and interaction as these intersect with issues of social inequality, social control, social change, and the everyday production of subjectivities.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3310 graduate standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Social Change and Development
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 4335).  Nature of social change and development. Emphasizes sociological theories of social change and development contrasting them with approaches from the disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: RU_SOC 1000 or SOCIOL 1000 and junior standing

courses.name: Environment and Society
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 4370). An interdisciplinary examination of domestic and international environmental issues focusing on social, cultural, and policy dimensions. Perspectives of the social sciences and humanities are included.

courses.name: Sociology of Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with  ED_LPA 7458 and SOCIOL 7410). Contexts, structures and processes of schooling; effects on class, race, ethnicity and gender; social change, educational policy, and organizational dynamics; higher education and the economy.

courses.name: Sociology of Social Policy
courses.description: Sociological theories and methodologies focused on social policy; policy as process; contextual and critical policy analyses; assessing policy effects and consequences.

courses.name: Social Movements and Conflicts
courses.description: Survey of approaches and research on social movements and social change. Historical and contemporary social movements in the U.S.; collective protest and violence; political revolutions. MA core course.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3520, SOCIOL 3700, or SOCIOL 3320 or graduate standing

courses.name: Political Sociology
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 4520). Social bases of power and politics, economic and political elites, the political economy of the advanced societies, sources of political conflict and change.

courses.name: Gender and Human Rights in Cross Cultural Perspective
courses.description: (same as WGST 4550 and PEA_ST 4550).  This course focuses on the global discourse on human rights and gender, emphasizing cross-cultural theories.  Course includes the meaning of rights, Western and non-western perspectives, feminist contributions, important substantive debates, violations, policymaking and activism.
courses.prerequisites: WGST 1120 or SOCIOL 2200; senior standing required

courses.name: Society and Social Control
courses.description: The concept of social control is analyzed from both micro and macro theoretical perspectives. Focus is on patterns of social domination.

courses.name: Drugs and Society
courses.description: Course will examine the social, political, and economic aspects of legal and illegal drug use in American society.  Issues include: theories of drug use, the social correlates of drug use, the war on drugs and policy alternatives, and the rise of the pharmaceuticals industry.  Graded on A/F basis only

courses.name: Sociology of Mental Health
courses.description: Course examines the social aspects of mental health and illness.  Topics include: stress and mental health, medicalization of behavior, stigma and labeling, mental health care systems, social correlates of mental health (such as gender, childhood, work status, and social support).
courses.recommendation: 1000 level sociology course or 1000 level Psychology course

courses.name: Internship in Sociology
courses.description: Professional experience under faculty supervision. Project must be arranged by student and faculty member prior to registration.

courses.name: Service Learning in Sociology
courses.description: Students participate in a variety of research-oriented, community service projects which illuminate and reinforce concepts introduced in various sociology courses. Repeatable twice for credit. Does not meet Arts and Science general education requirements.

courses.name: Special Readings in Sociology
courses.description: Extensive reading in selected area or special field.

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Integrates perspectives, methods, substantive foci of undergraduate courses. Analysis of sociology as a discipline and profession. Discussion of opportunities for graduate study, employment.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2950 and SOCIOL 3100 and senior sociology major

courses.name: Senior Seminar - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Integrates perspectives, methods, substantive foci of undergraduate courses. Analysis of sociology as a discipline and profession. Discussion of opportunities for graduate study, employment.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2950 and SOCIOL 3100 and senior sociology major

courses.name: Honors in Sociology
courses.description: Intensive work in a selected field within sociology, including readings and research. Repeatable up to 6 hours with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: for honors candidates; SOCIOL 2950 and SOCIOL 3100

courses.name: Topics in Sociology-Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated with departmental consent.

courses.name: Problems in Sociology
courses.description: Directed research not leading to thesis or dissertation.

courses.name: Feminist Research and Criticism
courses.description: (same as WGST 7110). Examination of both feminist critiques of traditional social research and recent, feminist-oriented research that attempts to answer these criticisms.

courses.name: Social Statistics
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 7120). Descriptive statistics and bivariate quantitative analysis techniques commonly used by social scientists. Includes coverage of parametric and non-parametric methods. Introduction to computer analysis.

courses.name: Social Inequalities
courses.description: Examination of theories and research concerned with inequalities based on social class, gender, and race-ethnicity. M.A. core course for sociology students.

courses.name: Sociology of Aging
courses.description: Sociological research and theories of aging and old age; historical, demographic, comparative, social psychological and structural topics are studied in depth.

courses.name: Race and Ethnic Relations
courses.description: The experience of racial and ethnic minorities; inequality, assimilation, ethnic and racial conflict, accommodation.

courses.name: Women, Development and Globalization
courses.description: (same as WGST 7230 and BL_STU 7230; cross-leveled with WGST 4230). Examines the history and structure of "development" discourse and practices. Stresses the interconnections and impact on women globally. Reviews women's strategies in defining and instituting programs to improve quality of life in communities.

courses.name: Social Perspectives on Gender and Emotion
courses.description: (same as WGST 7235, BL_STU 7235; cross-leveled with WGST 4235, SOCIOL 4235, BL_STU 4235).  Examines theories of affect and emotions, the social contexts and the implications for human development and behavior, with special emphasis on sex, gender, race, class and culture. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Comparative Social Institutions
courses.description: Analysis of selected social institutions such as agriculture, family, economy, education, health care, law, polity, religion. Inter-institutional and international comparisons.

courses.name: Death and Dying
courses.description: Death and dying explored from demographic, sociological and social psychological perspectives. Topics: trends and differentials; definitions of death; dying as a social process; funerals and survivors; cultural solutions to problems of death.

courses.name: Social Demography
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 7315). General demographic theories; age, sex, and ethnic composition of population; fertility, mortality and migration as components of population change; social, economic and political implications of demographic trends.

courses.name: Culture, Identity and Interaction
courses.description: Examines the interplay between culture, identity, and interaction as these intersect with issues of social inequality, social control, social change, and the everyday production of subjectives.

courses.name: Social Change and Development
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 7335). Nature of social change and development. Emphasizes sociological theories of social change and development contrasting them with approaches from the disciplines.

courses.name: Self, Language, and Social Life
courses.description: Examines the interplay between self, language, and social life. Particular attention is paid to how the everyday construction of inner lives relates to diverse social worlds. The effects of situational and institutional conditions as they shape identity and social interactions are important considerations.

courses.name: Environment and Society
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 7370). An interdisciplinary examination of domestic and international environmental issues focusing on social, cultural, and policy dimensions. Perspectives of the social sciences and humanities are included.

courses.name: Seminar in Sociology of Work
courses.description: Recent developments in the sociological study of occupations and professions. Surveys alternative theoretical perspectives and methodological approaches. Deals with rationalization, professionalization, alienation, class consciousness, self management.

courses.name: Sociology of Education
courses.description: (same as  ED_LPA 7458; cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4410). Contexts, structures and processes of schooling; effects on class, race, ethnicity and gender; social change, educational policy, and organizational dynamics; higher education and the economy.

courses.name: Community Social Structure
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 7446). A comparative study of communities in different nations and in urban and rural areas. A primary focus of the course will be on social change in communities, in response to changing economic, political, social, cultural, and ecological factors.

courses.name: Sociology of Social Policy
courses.description: Sociological theories and methodologies focused on social policy; policy as process; contextual and critical policy analyses; assessing policy effects and consequences.

courses.name: Social Movements and Conflicts
courses.description: Survey of approaches and research on social movements and social change. Historical and contemporary social movements in the U.S.; collective protest and violence; political revolutions.

courses.name: Political Sociology
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 7520). Social bases of power and politics, economic and political elites, the political economy of the advanced societies, sources of political conflict and change.

courses.name: Gender and Human Rights in Cross Cultural Perspective
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 7550 and WGST 7550). Focuses on the global discourse on human rights and gender, emphasizing cross-cultural theories. Course includes the meaning of human rights, western and non-western perspectives, feminist contributions, important substantive debates, violations, policymaking and activism.

courses.name: Seminar in Culture and Mass Media
courses.description: Sociological examination of culture and mass media, including institutional character, production and distribution, audience effects, relation of social structures. Current research, theories, methods.

courses.name: Society and Social Control
courses.description: The concept of social control is analyzed from both micro and macro theoretical perspectives. Focus is on patterns of social domination.

courses.name: Seminar in Family Sociology
courses.description: Research and theory on family structure and family life; in-depth study of a selection of topics and issues.

courses.name: Special Readings in Sociology for the Graduate Level
courses.description: Extensive reading in selected area or special field. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Sociology
courses.description: This graduate seminar will cover current issues in higher education, building a teaching portfolio, the daily work of teaching, and work/life balance in academia.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Critical Race Theory
courses.description: Critical examination of key sociological theories of race, racialization, and racism in contemporary society.

courses.name: Theoretical Thinking in Sociology
courses.description: Close analysis of the texts of classical and contemporary social theory.  Key concepts will be elaborated in the context of intellectual history, and will be applied to deepening the theoretical significance of an empirical research question on the student's emerging agenda.  Required for all entering graduate students in Sociology.

courses.name: Research in Sociology
courses.description: Research not expected to terminate in thesis or dissertation.

courses.name: The Logic of Social Research
courses.description: Meta-theoretical and conceptual issues at the core of design decision making, questionnaire construction, qualitative field techniques, interviewing, scaling, panel analysis, computer applications to qualitative data; experimental, survey and case study designs, ethics. Required for Ph.D. students.

courses.name: Advanced Social Statistics
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 8130). Introduction to multivariate analysis for social scientists. Emphasis on non-experimental applications of analysis of variance and correlation-regression. Computer applications emphasized.

courses.name: Seminar in Population Health
courses.description: Graduate Seminar on the social distribution of morbidity and mortality.  Covers major theoretical perspectives and the state of empirical evidence regarding several individuals and contextual explanations of health disparities.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Urban Sociology
courses.description: In this course we will survey the field of urban sociology.  Urban sociology is the study of human social relations in cities and urbanized communities.  We will consider urbanization in its preindustrial, industrial, and postindustrial forms in the U.S. and elsewhere.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar on Interview Theory and Technique
courses.description: The seminar has three goals: First is the consideration of literature dealing with recent theoretical formulations of the interview. This will provide a basis, second, for critically examining a number of popular interview guidebooks. The third goal is to offer the opportunity to put theory and technique into practice by analyzing selected interview material.

courses.name: Media and Power in Comparative Perspective Seminar
courses.description: This course traces the historical development of U.S. and selected international media systems.  We analyze and debate the relationship of differing media systems to political power, popular culture, and the facilitation or inhibition of democratic practices.  Students do comparative analyses of international media institutions and related analyzes of media content.
courses.prerequisites: undergraduate seniors may enroll with instructor's consent

courses.name: Race, Ethnicity, and Transnational Inequalities
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 8277).  This graduate seminar examines the global contest of our radicalized modern world system.  How do people develop and give meaning to race/ethnicity in different regions?  Focus on the construction of bodies Creole identities, gender, sexualities, citizenships and immigration.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar on Sustainable Development
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 8287). An interdisciplinary examination of sustainable development focusing on social, economic, cultural and environmental dimensions of development.  International and domestic issues and approaches to sustainable development are included.

courses.name: Seminar on Narrative and Identity
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing required; instructor's consent required

courses.name: Social Processes of Information/Knowledge Utilization
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 8425). Factors conditioning communication and diffusion of ideas and practices; exercise of personal influence; role of change agents and agencies in the process of change.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Medicine, Technology, and Globalization
courses.description: In the last two hundred years medicine and technology have transformed our day-to-day living as never before. They have permeated our social and personal imagination, our epistemological bearing, disciplinary practices, and not to forget national and global agendas. A key aspect of such transformations, which we are going to investigate in this course, has been the intertwining of medicine and technology in a variety of ways, resulting in wide ranging impact - from the emergence of medical gaze, transformation of healthcare practices, to present day transnationalization and globalization of medical practices. This course would utilize recent theoretical developments to interrogate different interrelated facets of medicine, technology, and globalization.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Criminology and Deviant Behavior
courses.description: Survey of empirical research and sociological theory in criminology and deviant behavior. May be repeated once with instructor's consent.

courses.name: Seminar on the Sociology of Health and Sickness
courses.description: Topical seminar dealing with one of three subject areas: (1) Health problems, disease, illness, sickness; (2) Occupations, and Organizations in the health field, or (3) Comparative Health Care Systems. Course may be repeated for different topics.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Advanced work leading to thesis or dissertation.  Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Sociological Theory I
courses.description: Traces development of sociological theory from the "generation of 1890" through the 1940s, including the work of Durkheim, Weber, Parsons and others.

courses.name: Seminar in Qualitative Methods in Sociology
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 9287). Examination of various qualitative methods of research, including problem-formulation, access and interpretation of data, theory-generation, and preparation of research reports.

courses.name: Ethnographic Fieldwork
courses.description: History of sociological ethnography, the analysis of key ethnographic texts, forms of ethnographic fieldwork, and recent debates related to representational practices.  Applications to participant observation, field interviewing, and strategies of discourse analysis in various social settings.

courses.name: Social Interaction Research
courses.description: Seminar on research methods in social interaction.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Environmental Discourses
courses.description: This seminar explores human cultural interactions with nature: how we understand ourselves in relation to space, how we interact with and learn about nature, and how we use nature.  Readings will include exemplary texts from sociology, geography and anthropology, science studies and cultural studies. Graduate Standing required.

courses.name: Seminar in Sociological Theory II
courses.description: Theoretical developments in sociology in Europe and United States since 1950. Recent formulations, controversies.

courses.name: Seminar in State and Economy
courses.description: Analysis of public policy and economic change in contemporary political-economic systems; growth of welfare state, capitalist planning, state socialist economics.

courses.name: Culture, Difference, and Inequality
courses.description: This course is an examination of exemplary, interdisciplinary texts employing a variety of cultural approaches to understanding difference and inequality.  In this seminar, we will think about what is gained from various cultural approaches to difference and inequality, now such approaches can be achieved methodologically, and how students can apply such approaches to their own research.  The main focus of the course is on cultural studies and poststructural feminist studies, but readings will also be included from intersectionality studies, affect studies, critical race studies and cultural sociology.
courses.prerequisites: restricted to Sociology graduate students or instructor permission

courses.name: Topical Seminar in Contemporary Sociological Theory
courses.description: Critical evaluation of selected points of view in current sociological theory. May be repeated with departmental consent.

courses.name: Topical Seminar in Historical Sociology
courses.description: Methodological approaches to sociological explanation of historical phenomena; related sociological theories of historical development, including Weberian, Marxist and other perspectives applied to a topical historical problem.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Body and Society
courses.description: The course is organized around three major themes - body as a site of personal and political experience; the social body, emphasizing the relationship between society, culture, and individuals; and the body as a site and instrument of politics.  Readings assigned for the course are aimed at critical engagement with the "body: within and across these themes.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Multivariate Analysis Techniques
courses.description: (same as RU_SOC 9837). Examination of various qualitative techniques of data analysis.

courses.name: Seminar in Sociology of Gender
courses.description: Analysis of recent research in which gender is a major focus. This research is chosen to exemplify a variety of theoretical perspectives, research strategies, and substantive topics.

courses.name: Independent Readings in Preparation f/Comprehensive Examinations
courses.description: Independent readings for PhD comprehensives. Open only to PhD candidates who have passed qualifying examinations.

courses.name: Seminar in Sociological Reasoning and Research Development
courses.description: Systematic development of sociological research integrating theory, method, and contributions to knowledge. Formulations of sociological problems, conceptual frameworks, research programs analytical strategies.
courses.prerequisites: SOCIOL 8120 or equivalent; departmental consent; doctoral standing
